title-group.article-title: Hans Jonas’ ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’, and Ludwig von Bertalanffy

author-notes.corresp: Roberto Franzini Tibaldeo, viale Regina Elena 25, Fossano, CN 12045, Italy Email: roberto.franzinitibaldeo@sssup.it

abstract.p: ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’ (published in Social Research, 1952) is indeed one of Hans Jonas’ most famous essays, to which its author reserved very deep attention during his philosophical career. As a former pupil of Martin Heidegger and Rudolf Bultmann, Jonas started to deal with religious topics, and specifically with Gnosticism, from the very outset of his philosophical career in the 1920s. After gaining recognition thanks to his remarkable philosophical-existential interpretation of Gnosticism, he returned to the modern age and its philosophical characters. Principally, Jonas discovered that modern philosophy up to Heidegger and Sartre suffered from a peculiar spiritual disease – namely, nihilism – that he had already traced in ancient Gnosticism and that he intended to reject. Therefore, Jonas’ acquaintance with ancient religion and thinking gave him a deep insight into the modern age and provided him with a first glimpse of what was later to become his biological philosophy. However, whoever could imagine that the idea of tracing similarities between Gnosticism and modern thinking came to Jonas at the beginning of 1950 from the famous philosopher and biologist Ludwig von Bertalanffy? In this article, I shall endeavour to demonstrate this thesis by quoting from unpublished documents. However, I shall also try to prove that Jonas did not follow von Bertalanffy’s advice completely. The overall aim is, therefore, both to highlight the origins of an essential turning point in the thinking of Hans Jonas, and, on such a basis, to outline the innovation and originality of his philosophical contribution.

sec.title: 1 Jonas’ interpretation of Gnosticism
sec.p: Hans Jonas’ philosophical interest in theological and religious matters has the opportunity to develop thanks to the fact that in the 1920s at the University of Marburg his teachers – the evangelical theologian Rudolf Bultmann and the philosopher Martin Heidegger – are bound by a fruitful philosophical friendship.1 Thanks to this friendship, the Jewish student Hans Jonas is allowed to attend Bultmann’s seminars on the exegesis of the New Testament, such as the one in 1925 on the fourth gospel.2

When Jonas completes his university studies, he decides to undertake a PhD thesis and, encouraged by Bultmann, he chooses to study the topic ‘Pistis und Gnosis’ [Faith and Knowledge].3 Indeed, he wants to find an answer to the following questions: ‘Why did the Church reject Gnosticism?…[W]hy was Gnosis as suchfrom Paul on rejected as a possible option? Why was Pistis chosen instead?’4 Therefore, Jonas begins his research with the recognition of the idea of gnosis. This is the only part of his work he actually carries out, because of the fact that this topic alone proves to be rather vast.

After his Promotion in 1928 Jonas works on two publications, both of which appear in 1930. The first is his PhD dissertation on the ‘idea of gnosis’,5 as an anticipation of the broader research contained in Gnosis und spätantiker Geist (1934 [this article quotes from the 3rd edn] and 1954 [again, quoting from the 3rd edn]). The second work is Augustin und das paulinische Freiheitsproblem.6 These publications testify that Jonas’ research topics (Gnosticism and Pauline-Augustinian Christianity) are the development of the former theme of ‘Pistis und Gnosis’. Moreover, these published works – which respectively focus on Gnostic dualism and human freedom – convey the same theoretical idea: from a historical point of view, the western Weltanschauung essentially evidences a nihilistic and contra-mundane tendency, the reasons of which ought to be investigated further and somehow overcome, in order to comprehend the authentic dynamics of human freedom and the ‘fundamental structure of the spirit as such’ (Jonas, 1930b: 82).

Indeed, Jonas believes that this result can be achieved by interpreting religious symbols with a ‘demythologized consciousness’.7 Faithful to Heidegger’s Daseinanalyse, Jonas is persuaded that, in its process of self-constitution, Dasein evidences a certain degree of ambivalence, which derives from the fact that Dasein is undeniably characterized by a ‘necessary, but non-casual nor inevitable motility…towards self-objectiveness [Selbstobjektivierung]’ (Jonas, 1930b: 82). The point is – states Jonas – that this essential human motility (that is, the motility of freedom) may easily give rise to a dualistic view of the relation between Dasein and the world, and between subject and object. Here – according to Jonas – lies the hermeneutical problem encountered by both Gnosticism and early Christianity in explaining human freedom and its relationship with the world.

I wish to highlight briefly the main feature of Jonas’ interpretation of ancient Gnosticism. Jonas aims to extend the idea of gnosis to the whole Hellenistic world, relating it to the notion of pistis. He intends to investigate the concept of gnosis from a hermeneutical perspective with its cultural and historical manifestations.8

However, Jonas’ real aim is to go beyond the historical and religious features of ancient Gnosticism in order to trace the main philosophical themes emerging from the Gnostic texts, which he summarizes as follows: ‘the creation of the world, the destiny of man, fall and redemption, the first and the last things’ (Jonas, 1958: xiii). He is interested in comprehending the origins of the great fresco of the divine and human adventure in the world as depicted in those texts. Jonas is attracted by the fascination exercised by gnosis on late antiquity, and by the fact that, since its origins, Christianity has fought inexhaustibly against Gnosticism. According to Jonas, if the Gnostic message of salvation had prevailed, ‘Our art and literature and much else would be different’ (ibid.: xiv). Jonas’ philosophical and – at least initially – Heideggerian approach to gnosis makes him aware of the need to clarify the basic existential features implied in that specific religious experience. He therefore wishes to pursue the following aim: ‘to understand the spirit speaking through these voices and in its light to restore an intelligible unity to the baffling multiplicity of its expressions’.9

Jonas tries also to find a solution for the origins of the Gnostic phenomenon, and he hypothesizes that behind its heterogeneous identity there actually is a common background, which he refers to as a Gnostic principle, which seems to unify the diverse Gnostic movements.10 According to Jonas, such unification consists of a whole set of ‘characteristic mental attitudes which are more or less distinctly exhibited throughout the whole group’ (Jonas, 1958: 26). However, since the Gnostic principle generally identifies all late ancient eastern spiritual movements, Jonas tries to generalize his philosophical conclusion: it may be that the ‘gnostic principle’ provides ‘if not the key to the whole epoch, at least a vital contribution toward its understanding’.11

The closing centuries of antiquity present – according to Jonas – a certain degree of ambivalence. On the one hand, they show a generalized situation of crisis, in which – as already hinted – also Christian faith is first involved. On the other hand, at the same time this epoch expresses widespread and deep spiritual and religious revival. Beneath its manifest heterogeneity, this phenomenon manifests, however, a certain degree of homogeneity, which Jonas identifies as follows: a ‘dualistic transcendent religion of salvation’ (Jonas, 1958: 32). Indeed, this spiritual and religious renewal underlines the absolute transcendence of God and emphasizes the existence of a radical ontological dualism between matter and spirit.12 These characters are also shared by both Christianity and Gnosticism, which – according to Jonas – among all religious constellations of this era, is the most representative. For this reason, precisely Gnosticism is the hermeneutical key employed by Jonas to comprehend all the other spiritual and religious movements of this historical period, and to trace their apparent differences back to their essential unity.13

However, at the same time Jonas wishes to clear the content of the Gnostic faith. In this respect, the Gnostic phenomenon is characterized by an incredible spirit of revolt against the classical and optimistic view of the world.14 Jonas shows that the word ‘gnosis’ – that is, knowledge as a vehicle of salvation – assumes a religious and divine meaning, and refers to a metaphysical context characterized by a radical form of dualism: the ‘cardinal feature of gnostic thought is the radical dualism that governs the relation of God and world, and correspondingly that of man and world’.15 God (the kingdom of light) absolutely transcends the world, which is the kingdom of darkness. The kosmos was created by lower powers (the Archons) and as a prison for those sparks of the divine substance that had had the misfortune to fall into the world and become imprisoned in the form of divine pneuma inside the human soul (psyche). Knowledge alone (gnosis), because of its divine origin, can succeed in freeing the pneuma, which will therefore be able to return to the kingdom of light. The whole of this process forms the ‘restoration of the deity’s own wholeness, which in pre-cosmic times has become impaired by the loss of portions of the divine substance’ (Jonas, 1958: 45). The man illuminated by gnosis becomes the ruler of his individuality. Whether he acts as an ascetic, or as a libertine, is indifferent, for in both cases the pneumatic morality highlights its hostility towards the world and every worldly bond, through which the Archons perpetuate the captivity of the divine sparks. As a result, the Gnostic moral theory appears to be acosmic,16 nihilistic and antinomic (i.e. contrary to the objective law – nomos – of this world).17

According to Jonas, all historical and literary expressions of Gnosticism share the same dualistic essence and after all prove to be nihilistic.18 All of these historical expressions are carefully analysed by Jonas, who is interested in grasping their common basic structure, that is, the Gnostic principle, the existence of which he could only guess at initially.19 The remarkable insight into these historical phenomena provided by the categories of Heidegger’s Daseinanalyse enables Jonas ‘to see aspects of gnostic thought that had been missed before’.20 This sounds – states Jonas – like a broad confirmation of their universal validity under a hermeneutical and ontological point of view. In other words, the reason for which Heidegger’s existential categories provide a fruitful interpretative key for a historical phenomenon such as Gnosticism, is that all human experience at any time may refer back to that specific philosophical approach.

However, after some time Jonas realizes that there is another possible answer to the question: the circularity, thanks to which the existential categories discovered by the Daseinanalyse had reached a deep insight into ancient Gnosticism, could simultaneously affect our contemporary age: the study of ancient Gnosticism – Jonas presumes – could be a way to acknowledge the essence of modernity and of its current effects.

Gradually, but quite unequivocally, Jonas begins to suspect that the reason for which Heidegger’s Daseinanalyse gained such a broad result in clarifying the dynamics of the Gnostic universe has nothing to do with the universal value of the existential categories. Jonas becomes aware of the fact that his master’s existential analysis could comprehend Gnosticism, since both Weltanschauungen already shared the same dualistic and nihilistic background.21 In other words, Jonas’ previous ‘“existentialist” reading of Gnosticism, so well vindicated by its hermeneutic success, invites as its natural complement the trial of a “gnostic” reading of Existentialism’ (Jonas, 1966: 213).

This is, actually, the aim of Jonas’ famous article ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’, published in 1952 in Social Research (Jonas, 1952). What had happened in the important interval between his first published studies on Gnosticism and this last work? What is evident is that Jonas emigrated from Nazi Germany, fought in the British army during the Second World War, tried to settle in Palestine in 1945, and finally decided to move with his family to Canada. What we also learn from ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’ is that in the meantime Jonas had parted not only from his former teacher and friend Heidegger (since his adhesion to Nazism in 1933), but also from his philosophy.

As he had already done with ancient Gnosticism, Jonas assumes preliminarily that existentialism is the philosophical outcome of modernity. In this respect, its existential categories are far from having universal validity. On the contrary, its basic features (nihilism and dualism) express the essence of the modern age as such.

sec.title: 2 Jonas’ criticism of modernity
sec.p: Just like late antiquity, the modern age is also characterized by a deep crisis, the origins of which – according to Jonas – date back to the 17th century, that is, ‘where the spiritual situation of modern man takes shape’ (Jonas, 1952: 430). In spite of their philosophical differences, both the founders of modernity, Pascal and Descartes, believe – just like the Gnostics – that the essence of ‘man’ is incommensurable with matter and worldly existence.22 This modern meaning of man’s solitude and alienation from nature bears some similarity with the Gnostic disappearance of the classical kosmos. Like Gnostics, modern man experiences the loss of his cosmic essence, that is, the loss of the belief according to which the value of man consists in his being a part of a whole.

However, Jonas is also aware of the fact that the Gnostic and the modern universes manifest deep differences. For the Gnostics, the universe is the artefact of lower divinities, which carry on their rebellion against the divinity of light and its design to regain power. Therefore, the Gnostic universe actively thwarts the divine will. On the contrary, the mathematical and scientific modern universe is absolutely indifferent towards man’s existence, final causes and teleology. The modern cosmic ontology is reduced to its materialistic and mechanical character only.23 Any other quality is therefore considered absurd, useless, or illusory. As a result – states Jonas – modernity extends nihilism to the whole ontology, while the Gnostics proclaimed their nihilistic belief solely in their ethical denial of an actively evil universe, and with the aim of returning to their eternal home.

If the universe is indifferent to value, human action cannot but represent the exploitation of a Nietzschian will to power, which – however – manifests its nihilistic essence.24 Another consequence of modernity is that nihilism affects the whole divinity. Also the Gnostic God is extra-mundane or, as Jonas says, ‘contra-mundane’ (Jonas, 1958: 251). However, the Gnostics were also offered a way out by the divinity of light: they could be allowed to gain enlightenment and the knowledge of their acosmic freedom. In other words, they could believe in salvation. On the contrary, although the Pascalian universe is created by God, it is also abandoned by God. The transcendent God becomes an unknown God, an agnostos theos – underlines Jonas – and ‘mankind’ is condemned to suffer the same fate.25 Indeed, Heidegger interprets Nietzsche’s antinomism as a nihilistic loss of the transcendent world.26 This signals another deep difference between Gnosticism and modernity: the existentialistic antinomism has no chance of becoming an ethical rebellion or of giving rise to an ethical commitment, as experienced by the Gnostics. Paradoxically, Sartre’s expression all is permitted to man 27 turns into nothing, for humankind has no opportunity at all of escaping its desperate and lonely condition of ‘innercosmic nihilism’ (Jonas, 1952: 447).

According to Jonas, Heidegger’s thinking expresses the same nihilistic drift of modernity. Jonas shows that Heidegger’s existential ontology and the attempt to comprehend being as temporality (see Sein und Zeit) is deeply problematical. In Heidegger’s view, the temporality of Dasein is such that the ‘present’ disappears and is no longer an autonomous dimension of time. For this reason, it offers no chance for existential authenticity.28 Following Jonas, this is the coherent effect of the historical and philosophical progress ending in a new form of dualism: the philosophy of existence and its deep ‘deprecation of the concept of nature’ as the extreme results of modernity’s solipsistic subjectivism.29

As a result, the matching of Gnosticism and modernity makes Jonas aware of the similarity that these two epochs are both characterized by dualism and nihilism. However, the modern nihilistic danger is more insidious, and modern dualism is more desperate and radical.30 In comparison with Gnostic nihilistic dualism, modernity experiences a more serious spiritual disease, that is, dualistic nihilism.

sec.title: 3 About the origins of Jonas’ criticism of modernity and its relation to Gnosticism: the role played by Ludwig von Bertalanffy
sec.p: Jonas has never concealed that the employment of Gnosticism as an overall hermeneutical key gave him the opportunity to recognize the limits of modern ontology and to develop a broader philosophical investigation in order to find a new ontology and a new form of ethics for our technological era.31 What is more, it is probable that long before 1952 – the year in which Jonas published ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’ – the philosopher had started to have doubts about the goodness of modernity’s philosophical results. However, in none of his published works, not even his posthumous autobiography Memoirs (Jonas, 2003), did he ever reveal if the idea of employing Gnosticism for a philosophical interpretation of the contemporary age had been suggested to him by someone else and, if so, by whom.

It is actually very likely, however, that the person who gave Jonas this suggestion was the famous philosopher and biologist Ludwig von Bertalanffy, and precisely in a letter dated 1 April 1950. I wish to describe briefly the circumstances of this interesting episode.

After the war Jonas and his family moved to Palestine. However, in 1949 Jonas resolves to emigrate to the more peaceful New World, precisely to Canada, a country with more opportunities for his family. From October 1949 to the end of the winter–spring term in 1950 Jonas is Lady Davis Fellow at the Dawson College of McGill University in Montreal (Quebec). However, Jonas never stops looking around for further job opportunities, which eventually come at the end of March 1950: he finds a position as visiting professor at Carleton College in Ottawa (Ontario), which he resolves to accept.

The first contact between Jonas and Ludwig von Bertalanffy occurs on 3 December 1949, when Jonas writes a letter in English to von Bertalanffy asking if he knows of possible posts as professor in Montreal. Unfortunately, von Bertalanffy cannot answer Jonas’ query, since he has just moved for academic reasons from Montreal to Ottawa, where he works at the Department of Biology of the Faculty of Medicine in the local university. Jonas encloses in his letter a ‘contribution from the philosopher’s angle to some problems of theoretical biology’,32 that is, the outline of the ‘philosophical biology’ that he was to develop in the following years.

We must imagine how pleased Jonas is, only a few days later, to receive a polite letter in German – their mother tongue – from von Bertalanffy, in which the biologist assures Jonas that he will read his manuscript in the Christmas holidays.33 As he promised, Bertalanffy reads the paper and then answers Jonas on 6 February 1950. In this letter we learn that Jonas’ manuscript is an early version of the famous ‘Is God a Mathematician?’, which he will publish in 1950 in Measure: A Critical Journal.34 Bertalanffy shows great interest and approval for many of Jonas’ statements. Jonas quickly writes back on 23 February 1950 thanking von Bertalanffy for his remarks. However, Jonas is also very concerned about his professional future, so he asks von Bertalanffy about any teaching opportunities in Ottawa. Von Bertalanffy suggests that Jonas ask at the Carleton College in Ottawa,35 where Jonas will actually find a post for the following years.

What is relevant for the present article, is that in his letter dated 15 March 1950 von Bertalanffy incidentally asks Jonas for a copy of Gnosis und spätantiker Geist (published in Europe in 1934 [this article quotes from the 3rd edn]), because of his interest in the same problem.36 Indeed, before becoming a biologist von Bertalanffy studied mysticism, with particular attention to the thinking of Nicholas of Kues. This was, in fact, the topic of one of his earliest publications.37

So Jonas sends his friend a copy of his book on Gnosticism. Von Bertalanffy’s answer to Jonas arrives only two weeks later (1 April 1950) and is absolutely remarkable.38 Von Bertalanffy is enthusiastic about Jonas’ book, which he has been able to browse through and of which he shares the general ideas. What is more, he admits that the reading of Gnosis und spätantiker Geist has enlightened him on one fact: the extraordinary similarity in the way the Gnostic era and the contemporary age develop (this is the meaning of the term ‘Gleichläufigkeit’ he uses in this regard).39 He therefore gives Jonas some advice: he should write a book which evidences ‘the parallels between the Gnostic era and ours’.40 Indeed, von Bertalanffy senses the relevance of Gnosticism in comprehending the contemporary age. This book ‘will undoubtedly become a bestseller’ – adds von Bertalanffy – ‘and you are the right man to write it!’.41

Moreover, it is noteworthy that the biologist gives Jonas some further suggestions for development – something that Jonas will actually do two years later in ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’: ‘The collapse of the Greeks’ general image of the world – from pre-Socratic philosophy up to Plato and the Stoics – and of the belief in the rationality of being. In our contemporary age: the crisis of Descartes’ and Newton’s image of the world and of the faith in science and progress and in machines.’42 As further elements of the contemporary era, von Bertalanffy adds the following: ‘the Philosophy of Weltangst – that is, existentialism’ as a modern example of Western Gnosis; the fact that Jonas’ statement according to which ‘The world was no longer an object of knowledge worthy of attention’,43 is actually true not only in late antiquity, but also in the present era, which is ‘pervaded by hostility towards reason’; the fact that ‘All in all Heidegger and Sartre are nothing but a Modern version of Gnosis, a version which uses slightly different terms’; finally, the fact that ‘In your book you have only to outline these questions to achieve the “analogies” with the Modern age’.44 It is on these precise elements that Jonas’ ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’ (1952) insists.

I believe that the relationship with von Bertalanffy gives Hans Jonas the decisive opportunity to make several elements of his criticism of modernity explicit. Jonas starts working on these elements in the so-called Lehrbriefe (‘didactic letters’), written in Italy during the war.45 His first published work on such topics as ‘Is God a Mathematician?’ (Jonas, 1951). In both works, his ground thesis is the inability of modern scientific and mechanistic thinking to comprehend the phenomenon of organic life. However, only the friendship with von Bertalanffy probably gives him the possibility of discussing his ideas with a scientist and at the same time of linking his criticism of modernity with ancient Gnosticism. Indeed, von Bertalanffy’s letter dated 1 April 1950 is the only document in which the biologist refers to Gnosticism, whereas in other writings he confirms his criticism towards modernity without referring to Gnosticism.

In this respect, I wish to quote two documents. The first is a letter von Bertalanffy writes to Jonas on 6 February 1950 after reading his earlier version of ‘Is God a Mathematician?’. Von Bertalanffy agrees with Jonas about the responsibility of the modern mechanistic view of nature and life in the genesis of the generalized crisis of contemporary thinking.46 The second document is an article published in the proceedings of a debate on science, biology and philosophy held in December 1950 and in which Jonas, too, was a participant.47 Here von Bertalanffy insists on the fact that the crisis of the modern age ‘needs new synthesis and a universal and profound reorientation’48 of science and philosophy, which he believes possible with his ‘general system theory’.

To return to the relationship between Gnosticism and modernity, if Jonas actually seems to have accepted his friend’s suggestion of connecting the two eras, it must be said that Jonas’ study is deeply original and develops the thesis in a different direction. In his letter dated 1 April 1950 von Bertalanffy suggests emphasizing the ‘persistence [Fortleben] of Gnosis’ in its historical development: ‘Gnosis – Areopagite – German mysticism – the Kusaner – Böhme – William Blake – etc.’.49 Jonas, however, does not aim at this, nor is he interested in deepening his understanding of ‘the mythical and fantastic idea of the world’ which characterizes some contemporary forms of Gnosis.50

Instead, as has been seen, Jonas has one clear aspiration: to use Gnosis as a hermeneutical key to the comprehension of modernity and its current nihilistic results. From other letters kept in his Nachlass we discover that Jonas develops these ideas at the end of 1951. The occasion to do this is a lecture – entitled ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism: a Comparison’ – that he plans to deliver in some North American universities.51 Finally, in the following year, he publishes ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’, one of his most important articles in Social Research – and its relevance for Jonas’ thinking is confirmed by the fact that in the following decades he will continue modifying and republishing it several times and in different languages.52 Indeed, we ought not to forget that this article represents an important step in Jonas’ philosophical research because of its polemical opposition not only to modernity, but also to Heidegger’s (his former master’s) irresolute and irresponsible thinking.53

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: It is definitely possible, although until now no documented proof has been found, that, in addition to von Bertalanffy, also other thinkers or biographical facts played a certain role in the development of Jonas’ meditation on the affinity between late ancient Gnosticism and the modern era. For instance, it is actually possible that the coeval criticism levelled at Heidegger’s philosophy of existence by a friend and university colleague of Jonas, Günther Anders, could also have played a part.54

However, what would be interesting to know is if Jonas did in some way ever repay his ‘debt’ towards von Bertalanffy for his suggestion, or if he felt any gratitude towards his friend, even though he did not actually follow his advice fully. On von Bertalanffy’s part, in his letter dated 1 April 1950 – which after all seems not to have been an April Fool’s Day jest – he jokes with his friend and says he is ready to receive, when Jonas has written the book, ‘a couple of bottles of whiskey as royalties for the first one hundred thousand’ copies sold.55 Jonas never wrote the book suggested by von Bertalanffy. However, he certainly became a well-known philosopher, whose books have sold (and continue to sell) hundreds of thousands of copies.

sec.title: Appendix
sec.p: Ludwig von Bertalanffy’s letter dated 1 April 1950
1 April 1950
Dear Hans,56

An after-thought: – 5 minutes after you left, one more good piece of advice came into my mind. Submit the matter and Carleton’s offer to Dr James. When I finished with the U[niversity] of Ottawa, he helped me and gave me a lot of worthy advice. Surely, he will do the same for you, and he feels a precise responsibility for us Davis scholars. Perhaps he might offer himself to write directly to Carleton, and, most of all, he may likewise set out in writing the question concerning the subsequent increase in remuneration. A third party – and especially James, thanks to his great prestige in Canada – can usually do more than the person directly involved. You can trust Dr James’ advice; in my experience, I know he manages these affairs and these relationships very well, and much better than us ‘newcomers’.

I have browsed through your book on Gnosis. Really superb – you are one of the few historians of philosophy who steer clear of the pedantry of philologists. Broad and wonderful insight. A piece of free advice: resolve to write a book on the parallels of the Gnostic era with ours. The similarity of their development is simply so astonishing – I see so much that has not yet been properly worked out – that the book will undoubtedly become a bestseller, and you are the right man to write it! I have scribbled down a couple of ideas that just came into my mind (and with which most likely you have been familiar for a long time):

The collapse of the Greeks’ general image of the world – from pre-Socratic philosophy up to Plato and the Stoics – and of the belief in the rationality of being. In our contemporary age: the crisis of Descartes’ and Newton’s image of the world and of the faith in science and progress and in machines.

‘Eastern’ and ‘western’ ‘Gnosis’: on the one hand, the Russians (Dostoevsky, Berdyaev, the tsarist philosophers of the third Rome, some of whom are persuaded of the link to ancient Gnosis; finally, also communism as a secularized and relatively coarsened form of eschatology). On the other hand, the philosophy of Weltangst – that is, existentialism. In addition, all the current forms of eschatological movements: the ‘second religiosity’ in America – the revivalist meetings – it really must be possible to build superficial and simple analogies with all of your Barbeliots and other fellows. All in all Heidegger and Sartre are nothing but a modern version of Gnosis, a version which uses slightly different terms.
On page 177 of your book: ‘The world was no longer an object of knowledge worthy of attention’. There, its precise parallel in the present-day movements pervaded by hostility towards reason.
Compare with: Rudolf Steiner, the Book of Mormon, Mrs McPherson57, etc.!

Also of interest are the effects of Gnosis on German Rococo: Wieland (Cerinthus, Apollonius of Tyana, etc.)58 – and the comparison of how the argument was treated ironically then, with how it is accepted seriously in the 20th century. Wieland’s genial novels have wrongly been forgotten.

The ‘Judgement Day’ is imminent. For the Gnostics, it was known as the Last Judgement, while for contemporary men, due to a technological pseudomorphosis, it takes the form of the hydrogen bomb. However, the fundamental attitude is the same.
And so on. In your book you have only to outline these questions to achieve the ‘analogies’ with the modern age.
What do you think about it? Should you write the book, I wish to subscribe to a couple of bottles of whiskey as royalties for the first one hundred thousand.

I have an objection against your Gnosis book, namely, that the relationship to early Christianity should have been deserved a much more scrupulous treatment. Above all, this affects: (1) Philo; (2) the relationship to the gospel of John; (3) the character of Marcion. Indeed, I believe that this was a conscious omission in relation to other investigations, especially Harnack’s.59 Does the announced second volume actually exist?60 It would be of extreme importance – all the more, since, as far as I know, a new interpretation of Plotin is still missing.

Instead, you should write something on the persistence of Gnosis, and precisely (a) of the persistence of great fundamental ideas (the ‘philosophia perennis’, to say it with Huxley), such as the thinking of negative theology: Gnosis – Areopagite – German mysticism – the Kusaner – Böhme – William Blake – etc. Presumably, a comparable line of thought may also be traced in the Jewish-Arab philosophy of the Middle Ages (the Jewish-Hispanic mystics? The Sufis?) – however, about this I really do not know. (b) of the mythical and fantastic idea of the world – and this takes us back to the book, you ought to write – 20th-century Gnosis.

By the way: is it not possible to identify certain elements of the Gnostic myth (which in fact did not come into existence thanks to ‘spontaneous generation’) even in previous ages? I think that a comparison would outline the presence of many elements of the Gnostic mythology already in the epic of Gilgamesh.

Anyway, from these random comments, you can understand the extent of my interest in your book. Sorry about my pencil – on Sunday mornings I lie in bed and enjoy myself with these unsystematic annotations. By now they have almost become a dissertation.
With my sincerest wishes, also from my wife and to yours,
Yours
LvB
NB. I have just read this letter after having copied it with my typewriter – it is more difficult to decipher than a late ancient palimpsest.
1. April 1950
Lieber Hans,

Treppenwitz: – 5 Minuten nach Deiner Abfahrt fiel mir noch ein guter Rat ein. Trage die Sache und das Carleton-Angebot Dr. James vor. Als ich mit der U. of Ottawa abschloss, hat er mir auch in sehr liebenswürdier [sic] Weise geraten und geholfen. Er tut es sicher auch in Deinem Fall gern, und fühlt gegenüber uns Davis-Leuten eine gewisse Verantwortung. Vielleicht trägt er sich selber an, ans Carleton zu schreiben, und kann zugleich besonders die Frage der späteren Gehalterhöhung schriftlich fixen. Ein Dritter – und zumal James mit seinem grosse Ansehen in Canada – kann gewöhnlich mehr tun, als der unmittelbar Beteiligte. Du kannst Dich auf den Rat Dr. James’ unbedingt verlassen; er meint es, wie ich aus eigener Erfahrung weiss, wirklich gut, und kennt die Verhältnisse weit besser wie wir ‘Zugereisten’.

Habe in Deinem Gnosis-Buch geblättert. Ganz ausgezeichnet – Du bist einer der wenigen Philosophie-Geschichtler, die keine philologischen morons sind. Weite und schöne Perspektiven. Mein unmassgeblicher Rat: settle Dich mit Deinen 3.500 – und schreibe ein Buch: Parallele der gnostischen Zeit mit unserer. Die Gleichläufigkeit ist ja doch erstaunlich – so viel ich sehe, noch nie richtig herausgearbeitet – das müsste ein bestseller werden, und Du wärst der Mann, es zu schreiben! Ich kritzle ein paar Gedanken, die mir gerade einfallen (und die Dir wahrscheinlich schon längst vertraut sind):

Zusammenbruch des grossen griechischen Weltbildes – von der Vorsokratik bis Platon und der Stoa –, des Glaubens an die Rationalität des Seins. Bei uns: Erschütterung des Cartesianisch-Newtonischen Weltbildes, des Glaubens an science, progress, Maschine.

‘Östliche’ und ‘westliche’ ‘Gnosis’: auf der einen Seite die Russen (Dostojewski, Berdjajew, die zaristischen Philosophen des Dritten Rom, teilweise bewusst an die alte Gnosis anknüpfend; schliesslich auch der Kommunismus als säkularisierte und entsprechend vergröberte Eschatologie). Auf der andern die Philosophie der Weltangst – Existentialismus und all das. Dazu all die eschatologischen Strömungen heutzutage: ‘zweite Religiosität’ in Amerika – die revivalist meetings – es müssten sich geradezu läppische und wörtliche Übereinstimmungen mit all Deinen Barbelioten und anderen Fellows herstellen lassen. Ebenso wie der ganze Haidegger [sic] und Sartre nur Modernisierung der Gnosis, mit bisserl andern Worten, ist.
Seite 177 Deines Buches: ‘Die Welt war kein würdiges Objekt der Anschauung mehr’.61 Die genaue Parallele in den ratio-feindlichen Szrömungen [sic] unserer Tage.
Vergleich mit: Rudolf Steiner, Buch Mormon, Mrs. McPherson, etc.!

Interessant auch die Auswirkung der Gnosis im deutschen Rokoko: Wieland (Kerinthos, Apollonius von Tyana, etc.) – und Vergleich der Ironie der Behandlung dort mit dem Ernst-nehmen im 20. Jahrhundert. Wielands geistreiche Romane sind sehr zu Unrecht verschollen.

Der ‘jüngste Tag’ steht vor der Tür – für die Gnostiker in Gestalt des Weltgerichtes – für die Heutigen (in technologischer Pseudomorphose) als die Wasserstoffbombe – aber das Grundgefühl ist das gleiche.
Und so weiter. Man braucht nur in Deinen Buch Stricherln [sic] an den Rand zu machen und hat schon die modernen ‘Homologien’.
Was denkst Du darüber? Ich abonniere mich auf ein paar Flaschen Whiskey als Royalties für die ersten Hunderttausend, wenn Du das Buch schreibst.

Einen Einwand habe ich gegen Dein Gnosis-Buch, nämlich, dass die Beziehung zum Frühchristentum wohl eingehendere Behandlung verdient hätte. Dies betrifft vor allem wohl: 1. Philon; 2. die Beziehung zum Johannes-Evangelium; 3. die Figur Marcions. Ich vermute allerdings, dass diese Unterlassung bewusst war in Hinblick auf andere Forschungen, Harnack besonders.62 Existiert eigentlich der angekündigte 2. Band? Der wäre doch sehr wichtig – umsomehr [sic], als es, so viel ich weiss, eine neure Plotin-Darstellung gar nicht gibt.

Hingegen müsstest Du einmal über das Fortleben der Gnosis schreiben, u. zw. a) der grossen bleibenden Grundgedanken (der ‘Philosophia perennis’, mit Huxley zu reden), z.B. die Linie der negativen Theologie: Gnosis – Areopagita – deutsche Mystik – der Kusaner – Böhme – William Blake – etc. Wahrscheinlich gibt es auch in der jüdisch-arabischen Philosophie des Mittelalters eine ähnliche Linie (jüdisch-spanische Mystiker? Sufiten?) – aber davon weiss ich nichts. b) des phantastischen Weltmythos – und das führt zurück zu dem Buch, das Du schreiben müsstest – die Gnosis des 20. Jahrhunderts.

Apropos: gehen nicht gewisse Elemente des gnostischen Mythos (der ja auch nicht durch ‘Urzeugung’ entstanden ist) noch viel weiter zurück? Ich denke, ein Vergleich würde zeigen, dass viel der Mythologie der Gnosis schon im Gilgamesch-Epos zu finden ist.

Jedenfalls, Du siehst aus diesen Randbemerkungen, wie sehr Dein Buch mich interessierte. Entschuldige den Bleistift – ich faulenze den Sonntag-Morgen im Bett und amüsiere mich dabei mit diesen unsystematischen Bemerkungen. Jetzt ist’s beinahe eine Abhandlung geworden.
Mit allen herzlichen Wünschen, auch von meiner und an Deine Frau,
Dein
LvB

However, like his teacher Heidegger, he is also persuaded that this is ‘the nature and risk of historical interpretation, which has to take its cues from an initial impression of the material and is vindicated only by the result, its intrinsic convincingness or plausibility, and above all by the progressively confirmatory experience of things falling into their place when brought into contact with the hypothetical pattern’ (ibid.). Jonas (1958: 42). The basic principles of Gnosticism – which aims to find an answer to a dualistic and ‘dislocated metaphysical situation’ – may be summarized in the ideas of ‘an antidivine universe, of man’s alienness within it, and of the acosmic nature of the godhead’ (ibid.: 236).

The redemptive alienation from the world and the Gnostic acosmic tendency correspond respectively to the German nouns Entweltlichung and Entweltlichungstendenz (Jonas, 1934 [citing 3rd edn]: 87; 1954 [citing 3rd edn]: 2–3). Culianu notes that the term Entweltlichung was first used by Max Weber to indicate Gnostic intellectualism (Culianu, 1985: 36–7).
However, according to Jonas ‘the antinomian libertinism exhibits more forcefully than the ascetic version the nihilistic element contained in gnostic acosmism’ (Jonas, 1958: 46).

‘The gnostic God is not merely extra-mundane and supra-mundane, but in his ultimate meaning contra-mundane. The sublime unity of cosmos and God is broken up. God and world, God and nature, spirit and nature, become divorced, alien to each other, even contraries. God as the negation of the world has a nihilistic function with regard to all inner-worldly attachments and values’ (Jonas, 1958: 251–2). See also Jonas (1934 [citing 3rd edn]: 149, 150, 249). The same dualistic-nihilistic character identifies also Gnostic anthropology (cf. ibid.: 239–41; 1958: 264).

Jonas identifies the following (mythical) features of Gnosticism: the life of the spirit (pneuma) is foreign to the kosmos; the pneuma is ‘beyond’ and ‘without’ ‘this world’, since it belongs to the ‘other world’; the pneuma is alien to the kosmos; there is a persistent struggle between light and darkness, and between life and death; there is the image of the dispersal of the one and the many, and of the sparks of light within darkness; there are the themes of the ‘fall’, ‘sinking’ and ‘capture’ of the divine sparks within matter; God has abandoned the kosmos, so, on the one hand, the pneumaticos (‘spiritual men’) are caught by dread and homesickness for the divine home, while, on the other hand, most of humankind is caught by numbness, sleep, intoxication and forgetfulness of its ignorant mundane life; salvation is a ‘call from without’ the world, a call proclaimed by the Divine Messenger or by the Alien Man; the call is, therefore, characterized by remembrance, promise, education, awakening, while the answer to the call implies faith, knowledge and hope (Jonas, 1934 [citing 3rd edn]: 92–140; 1958: 48–99).

Jonas (1966: 211). The 9th essay of The Phenomenon of Life (ibid.: 211–34) is a revised version of ‘Gnosticism and Modern Nihilism’ (Jonas, 1952), upon which we will shortly comment. Jonas republished this article several times, often modifying its content. For instance, in The Phenomenon of Life Jonas not only changes the former title to ‘Gnosticism, Existentialism, and Nihilism’, but also adds a brief introduction to the topic (Jonas, 1966: 211–13). For a summary of these changes, see Frogneux (2001: 62 ff.); Franzini Tibaldeo (2009: 38–47). Among the characteristics of Gnosticism, Jonas sees – for example – the hermeneutical fruitfulness of Heidegger’s ‘Geworfenheit’ in comprehending the ‘being thrown into the world’ of Gnostic life (Jonas, 1958: 64).

‘The extended discourse with ancient nihilism proved – to me at least – a help in discerning and placing the meaning of modern nihilism: just as the latter had initially equipped me for spotting its obscure cousin in the past. What had happened was that Existentialism, which had provided the means of a historical analysis, became itself involved in the results of it…Thus the meeting of the two, started as the meeting of a method with a matter, ended with the bringing home to me that Existentialism, which claims to be the explication of the fundamentals of human existence as such, is the philosophy of a particular, historically fated situation of human existence: and an analogous (though in other respects very different) situation had given rise to an analogous response in the past’ (Jonas, 1966: 212). With the term ‘Existentialism’ Jonas refers polemically not only to Heidegger, but also to the broader philosophical tendency of modernity, which originates with Pascal and Descartes, develops with Nietzsche, and culminates with Heidegger and Sartre (Hirsch Hadorn, 2000: 67 ff.; Uhtes, 2006: 43). For comments on Jonas’ criticism of Gnostic nihilistic dualism and Heideggerian Daseinanalyse, see Culianu (1985: 119–29); Volpi (1989a); Colpe (1994); Vogel (1995); Jakob (1996: 229 ff.); Baum (1997: 124 ff.); Hirsch Hadorn (2000: 67–88); Taminiaux (2001); Frogneux (2001: 61–100); Lazier (2003); Harms (2003: 278–99); Wiese (2004a: 292–4); Bonaldi (2005: 155–8); Lenzig (2006: 112–17); Wiese (2007). See also the interview with Jonas entitled ‘Gnostizismus heute?’ (Jaeschke, Schulte and Theunissen, 1994). For other comments (with no reference to Jonas) on the Gnostic character of Heidegger’s thinking, see Bréhier (1942–3); S. A. Taubes (1954); Volpi (1989b: 260–1).
